Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Electronically-Scanned Wideband Digital Aperture Antenna Arrays using Multi-Dimensional Space-Time Circuit-Network Resonance: Theory and Hardware

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
An aperture array is a group of antennas that can be deployed in particular geometric patterns to detect radio signals at a given range of frequencies. Using an array is beneficial for electrical engineering because it can magnify a radio signal in the direction of that signal while suppressing noise and interference through a process known as beamforming. In addition, an antenna array can be used to detect the direction and distance of the signal's source. Aperture arrays are a crucial component of scientific instruments that measure the spatial distribution of radio sources. For example, radio telescopes, such as the Square Kilometer Array (SKA) instrument, rely on aperture arrays to generate precise radio images of electromagnetic sources for experimental cosmology and space science. These instruments image the sky using closely spaced radio beams known as radio pixels. Closely packed sets of such beams can be achieved by using hexagonal pixel grids, which are considered ideal for scientific studies. In order to build aperture beamformers to be used for a specific purpose, efficient schemes for processing the antenna array signals must be developed to reduce the computing time, energy consumption, and costs for the hardware required in the system. The proposed research creates new algorithms and digital computing architectures that will produce highly-focused hexagonal radio pixels for the most demanding of microwave imaging applications. The same aperture arrays are used in radar and wireless communication systems for signature detection and signal intelligence. In fact, aperture arrays are absolutely essential for national security and public safety from a threat detection perspective. In addition to its scientific merits and benefits for national security, this project will train highly qualified personnel (HQP), who will contribute to commercial industry, scientific research, public safety agencies, and the defense sector. Specific efforts will focus on promoting Women in Engineering programs in higher education to recruit and guide female engineering students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.

The proposed research tackles the problem of highly directional sparse aperture arrays using the mathematical properties of multi-dimensional recursive digital filters. The NSF-sponsored effort will develop hardware systems for aperture arrays based on the proposed concept of network-resonant phased-arrays (NRPAs). Multi-dimensional (MD) circuit theory and digital hardware form an enabling technology for imaging algorithms that can greatly improve performance over traditional technologies. This research proposes groundbreaking techniques based on array signal processing, circuits and systems. It will result in a significant improvement in the directional sensitivity while using a lower number of array elements compared to traditional phased array receivers of the same sensitivity. The proposed NRPAs combine the concept of network resonance with phased array technology to gain significant improvement in both directionality and sensitivity. The MD circuit theoretical concept of network resonance allows digital beamformers to have complex pole manifolds. These properties are shown to have advantages in terms of ultra-wideband frequency response, exceptional directionality, multi-beams with shape control, rapid steerability, and low computational complexity. This project investigates radio beams with a hexagonal sky-print for optimal sensing and microwave imaging over wide fields-of-view and bandwidths. The proposed NRPAs will be extended to both sparse and random arrays via theoretical formulations for decreasing hardware cost, reducing energy expended in computers and increasing design flexibility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

This research tackled the problem of directional sparse aperture arrays using the mathematical properties of multi-dimensional recursive digital filters.  

The NSF-sponsored effort develod hardware systems for aperture arrays based on the proposed concept of network-resonant phased-arrays (NRPAs). Multi-dimensional (MD) circuit theory and digital hardware form an enabling technology for imaging algorithms that can improve performance over traditional technologies. This research proposes MD signal processing techniques based on radio-frequency (RF) digital and analog array signal processing, circuits and systems. The proposed NRPAs combine the concept of network resonance with phased array technology to gain improvement in both directionality and sensitivity at the cost of other trade-offs, such as, non-linear phase response and larger critical path delays. The MD circuit theoretical concept of network resonance allows digital beamformers to have complex pole manifolds. These properties are shown to have advantages in terms of ultra-wideband frequency response, high directionality, multi-beams with shape control, rapid steerability, and low computational complexity.

Intellectual Merit 

During the course of this NSF project, the PI and his graduate students at the University of Akron, Ohio, have obtained competence in the below areas of strength:

1. Design and implementation of radio receivers at the board level using off-the-shelf microwave electronics.

2. Design of antennas using a combination of theory, simulation and experience.

3. Digital receiver design (both theory, analysis, synthesis, simulation, fabrication, instrumentation, test, verification), including noise matching, power matching, mutual coupling in arrays, noise coupling, noise temperature, receiver sensitivity, quantization effects, correlation and uncorrelated LNA noise, noise bandwith, distortion mechanisms in receivers, inphase-quadrature (IQ) imbalance and local oscillator (LO) self-mixing issues, phase noise, oscillation and instabilities in receivers, aperture and edge effects of highly-sensitive array receivers.

4. Knowledge and experience in field programmable gate array (FPGA) and very large scale integration (VLSI) computer architecture designs of software defined radio (SDR) algorithms

5. Network connectivity and FPGA intellectual property (IP) core integration.

6. Competence in using CASPER software tools, reconfigurable open architecture computing hardware (ROACH)-version 2 FPGA design, and introduction to Xilinx radio frequency (RF) system on chip (SoC) platform (VCU 1275).

7. FPGA realization of phased-arrays, timed-arrays, multi-beam arrays, approximate-discrete Fourier transform (DOT) algorithms, 2-D/3-D finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters and filterbanks for multi-beam beamforming,  radar technologies and digital architectures.

Two fully-operational FPGA based digital arrays, operating at 2.4 GHz and 5.8 GHz were designed, implementated and tested during this project. The arrays were of 16 and 32 elements, respectively, and operated in receive mode only. 

Broader Impacts

The project findings resulted in multiple conference talks and papers, journal articles, and an organized Special Issue on Array Signal Processing in Springer Multi-Dimensional Systems and Signal Processing Journal. One conference paper titled  ``Real-Time 2-D FIR Trapezoidal Digital Filters for 2.4 GHz Aperture Receiver Applications'' has won a best paper award at  IEEE MERCON 2018. The PI and team of collaborators organzied and taught a workshop on Security-Aware Digital Phased-Array Design, at Naval Surface Warefare Center, Crane, IN. Dr. Madanayake gave a talk titled ``FPGA Signal Processing for Element-wise Digital Multi-Beam Array Transceivers'' at the University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka, and an invited talk at Florida Internartional University, titled  ``Analog and RF Digital Signal Processing Circuits for Massively Multibeam Arrays''. The PI and his team attended DARPA Microsystems Technology Office (MTO) Proposer?s Day on the mm-wave digital arrays (MIDAS) program, where a poster was presented. A graduate student contributed  a poster titled ``ROACH-2 based Prototype Implementation of an 8-Beam Multiplierless Approximate-DFT Based Aperture Array Receiver'' at the  2017 Casper Workshop, held at CalTech.

The project supported a female undergraduate researcher via a research experience for undergraduates (REU) supplement. Working demonstrations of linear array digital beamformers were on display at the 2018 Brooklyn 5G Summit, and this demo is archived on IEEE TV.

A Keynote speech was delivered by the PI at IEEE Mercon, held at the University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka.

Other broader impact activities include organization of several special sessions on related topics at IEEE conferences, editorship of a Special Issue on Array Processing in a prominent journal, FPGA design workshops for regional graduate students, hosting of several international visiting students and scientists at the PI's lab, and an educational outreach workshop at Norfolk State Univesity (NSU) in collaboration with Dr. Makarand Deo.

 

The PI is grateful to NSF for financial support. He thanks Dr. George Haddad, Dr. Hao Lin, Dr. Akbar Sayeed, and Dr. Jenshan Lin for their service at NSF.
